DOCNAME: MC ILVANNY v. THE UNITED KINGDOM
TEXT: The applicant is a NORP citizen born in DATE and currently serving a life sentence in FAC . He is represented by PERSON and PERSON , solicitors practising in GPE . ORG ( “ the Government ” ) were represented by their Agent , Mr PERSON of ORG , GPE .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .
On DATE the applicant was convicted of murder , committed on DATE . He received a mandatory life sentence . The trial judge made no indication as to the length of sentence to be served .
In DATE , ORG of the NORP Executive informed prisoners such as the applicant of proposed changes in the law affecting life prisoners LAW ) PERSON ) .

On DATE , certain provisions of LAW ) ( GPE ) Act DATE ( “ the DATE LAW ) came into force bringing the law governing the release of adult mandatory life prisoners into line with discretionary life prisoners and those convicted of murder under DATE . LAW required the punishment part of life sentences to be fixed by a court and hearings to be held in respect of existing life prisoners .
On DATE , ORG referred the applicant ’s case to ORG of Justiciary for a hearing under paragraph CARDINAL of the Schedule to the CARDINAL Act .

On DATE , the preliminary review committee ( GPE ) indicated , by means of a recommendation to ORG , that he would receive his first formal review by ORG after he had served DATE . While noting the savageness of the offence and numerous misconduct reports , the GPE also took into account his recent improvement in response in prison .

On DATE , the applicant applied for an extension of time to lodge a note of appeal against sentence , claiming that the judge ought to have backdated his sentence to the date when he was fully committed .

On DATE , ORG of Justiciary held a punishment part hearing in respect of the applicant . Lord PERSON ordered that DATE be served before release on licence . At that time it was the opinion of ORG that no account could be taken of circumstances following the conviction of an existing life prisoner , such as good conduct in prison or the existence of a date previously intimated as a date for first formal review of his case by ORG .
The applicant appealed this decision , inter alia , claiming that he had been told in prison that his case would be reviewed from the DATE point .
On DATE and CARDINAL DATE the court granted the applicant an extension of the time - limit for lodging a note of appeal .
On DATE , the applicant lodged his note of appeal .

On DATE the case of PERSON v. HMA DATE JC CARDINAL was decided in ORG of Justiciary . On DATE , the court granted leave to appeal to ORG in that case , which inter alia raised issues as to length of proceedings under LAW where a punishment part hearing was held some time after the original trial proceedings .
On DATE , ORG held a hearing on the applicant ’s sentence . It upheld his appeal and backdated his sentence to DATE .
On DATE , the applicant lodged an extension of time request to lodge a note of appeal against the setting of the punishment part of his sentence on DATE . On DATE , the court granted the extension .
On DATE , the applicant lodged his appeal against the punishment part , with grounds of appeal .
On DATE , the applicant lodged a devolution minute , raising various issues of legislative competence and Convention rights .
In DATE , Lord PERSON issued his report to the appellate court .
On DATE , at first sift , the court refused leave to appeal .
On DATE , at second sift , the court granted leave .

On DATE , ORG delivered judgment in PERSON v. ORG ( CARDINAL PERSON ( PC)CARDINAL and remitted it for decision by ORG , finding that the provisions of the DATE Act were compatible with Convention rights and that events after DATE of the original conviction and sentence could be taken into account in a punishment part hearing of an existing life prisoner . In dismissing the appellants’ Convention complaints , Lord PERSON of PERSON rejected the argument that the appellants’ rights to a fair trial within a reasonable time had been violated due to the opening up of the case and the amendment of sentence DATE . He stated :

“ This is a highly artificial argument since the original proceedings were completed within a reasonable time for the purposes of Article CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) . Since then , in Convention rights’ terms , the appellants’ position has been governed by LAW ) . In any event it is now accepted that in terms of Article CARDINAL ) the determination of the period to be served by the appellants as a punishment should have been made by the judge as part of the trial and not by ORG . The legislation and the punishment part hearings under paragraph CARDINAL are designed to cure this violation . Since the punishment part proceedings themselves have not violated the reasonable time guarantee in Article CARDINAL ) , there is no basis for holding that , overall , that guarantee had been breached in these cases . ”
By letters dated DATE and DATE and DATE , the applicant ’s solicitor wrote to the court inquiring about the hearing date for the appeal .
In DATE , the NORP Executive lodged its report about the applicant ’s conduct in prison and any expectations under previous release arrangements .

By decision of DATE , ORG noted the horrific nature of the crime ( his victim was stabbed CARDINAL times ) and his record in prison of CARDINAL misconduct reports ( including CARDINAL positive drugs tests ) . It concluded that he was not a person appropriately directing himself in relation to arrangements for his release and that there was no basis for making any discount on the CARDINAL-year period .
On DATE , the applicant ’s punishment part of his sentence will expire .
